name: Renal Fibromuscular Dysplasia
description: Renal fibromuscular dysplasia is the most common manifestation of FMD, affecting 60-75% of patients. It predominantly affects young to middle-aged women and is a significant cause of secondary hypertension. The characteristic 'string of beads' appearance on angiography distinguishes medial fibroplasia from other types. Treatment with percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (WITHOUT stent) is highly effective for renovascular hypertension, with cure or improvement in the majority of patients.

statement.text: Renal fibromuscular dysplasia is the most common FMD manifestation (60-75%), presenting with renovascular hypertension in young women, characterized by 'string of beads' appearance, and treated with PTA WITHOUT stent achieving 85-95% cure or improvement.
statement.formal: Renal FMD: Young Woman + Hypertension + String of Beads (Mid-Distal Renal Artery) → PTA WITHOUT Stent → 85-95% Cure/Improvement of Hypertension

explanation.intuition: When a young woman has difficult-to-control high blood pressure, suspect that narrowing in the kidney arteries (from FMD, not cholesterol) is the culprit. A simple balloon angioplasty can cure her hypertension.
explanation.key_insight: Unlike atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis (which is ostial and requires stenting with poor results), FMD is mid-to-distal and treated with angioplasty alone. Stenting is avoided because FMD lesions don't recoil like atherosclerotic ones and stent complications outweigh benefits.
explanation.technical_details: Medial fibroplasia (most common type) shows string of beads with beads LARGER than normal lumen on angiography. Treatment is PTA without stent. Success rates for hypertension cure (35-50%) or improvement (40-50%) are excellent, far better than atherosclerotic disease.

epidemiology.frequency_in_fmd: 60-75% of FMD patients have renal involvement
epidemiology.prevalence_in_hypertension: Accounts for <1% of all hypertension, but significant in young hypertensives

presentation: Acute renal function decline with ACE-I/ARB
treatment: PTA WITHOUT stent for symptomatic stenosis

medial_fibroplasia.pathology: Alternating areas of thinned media and fibromuscular ridges
medial_fibroplasia.appearance: String of beads with beads LARGER than normal lumen
medial_fibroplasia.location: Mid to distal renal artery (spares ostium)

hypertension.pattern: Resistant or difficult-to-control hypertension in young patient

renal_dysfunction.progressive: Chronic ischemic nephropathy (less common than atherosclerotic)

renal_infarction.mechanism: Dissection or thromboembolism from FMD lesion

catheter_angiography.advantage: Can perform angioplasty in same session

string_of_beads.key_feature: Beads LARGER than normal lumen (medial fibroplasia)

medical_management.first_line: Antihypertensive medication for blood pressure control

pta.rationale: FMD lesions have less elastic recoil than atherosclerotic lesions, so stent risks outweigh benefits

technique.sizing: Balloon sized to adjacent normal artery

surgical_treatment.historical: Previously main treatment, now rarely needed

multivessel_fmd.screening: Consider CTA/MRA from head to pelvis

associated_conditions.cerebrovascular_fmd: Screen for if renal FMD diagnosed

clinical_pearls: Young woman with hypertension = think renal FMD
String of beads with beads LARGER than lumen = medial fibroplasia
PTA WITHOUT stent for renal FMD (unlike atherosclerotic disease)
85-95% cure or improvement of hypertension with angioplasty
learning_objectives: Describe the classic angiographic appearance of renal fibromuscular dysplasia
Explain why stenting is avoided in renal FMD treatment
Compare outcomes of angioplasty for FMD versus atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis

related.relationship: FMD is an important cause of renovascular hypertension

sources.citation: Gornik HL, et al. First International Consensus on the diagnosis and management of fibromuscular dysplasia. J Hypertens. 2019;37(2):229-252
sources.organization: FMD Society of America and European FMD Initiative

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, 9th Edition
